quizSrc.term: What characterises an audience that has been mentally persuaded by your message?
quizSrc.definition: They generate more positive thoughts than negative thoughts  They have accepted your argument

quizSrc.term: What characterises an audience that has been mentally persuaded by your message?
quizSrc.definition: They generate more positive thoughts than negative thoughts  They have accepted your argument

quizSrc.term: What behavioural cues would signal that the audience has been persuaded by your message?
quizSrc.definition: They would display enthusiasm in their gestures and body language  They are likely to ask 'how' questions

quizSrc.term: Why is Petty and Cacioppo's model of persuasion so influential?
quizSrc.definition: It specifies situations when an audience is likely to engage with the message  It argues that the audience is actively judging your presentation.

quizSrc.term: Why is persuasive communication challenging?
quizSrc.definition: Because you have to understand the needs of the audience

quizSrc.term: You have a difficult colleague who is attacking you and others in your meeting. Should you:
quizSrc.definition: Find a way to end the meeting and reschedule or impose a 15 minute break.

quizSrc.term: You lose a major client. When explaining what has happened to your leadership team you:
quizSrc.definition: Determine whether they are a client you want to keep or not and seek out options to repair the relationship.  Analyse what happened, take responsibility, seek more learning and refocus on who is your ideal client and how to get more of them.

quizSrc.term: In a meeting, your colleague has a different point of view to you. Do you:
quizSrc.definition: Find out why the person believes what they do and negotiate a solution.

quizSrc.term: A colleague gets promoted over you and you don't think they should have been promoted. Every time something goes well, they claim responsibility. Do you:
quizSrc.definition: Reflect on what it is the other person has that you want. Then communicate to your superiors what you want without shame, blame or attack.  Let the boss know you want to be promoted. Then every time you succeed, let your boss informally know.

quizSrc.term: You are with a client and you find out what is important to them. Then you make them an offer based on what they've told you. They don't look convinced. Do you:
quizSrc.definition: Assume you haven't found out clearly enough what they want and go back to questioning them.  Realise they're not the ideal client for you and thank them for their time.

quizSrc.term: You are triggered in a meeting and start to feel frustrated. Do you:
quizSrc.definition: Take time out and when you feel calm assess what happened and why, then have the conversations you need.  Assess what you value, see which ones are flexible and whether your environment fits your values which are non-negotiable.  Check in with yourself, see what's coming up and ask yourself what you need in that moment.

quizSrc.term: If a message has three parts, beginning, middle and end, where does the problem-solution-benefit part of presentation come in?
quizSrc.definition: Middle part

quizSrc.term: Is it important or not important to learn how information is processed during communication?
quizSrc.definition: It is important because the knowledge will help us understand the processing needs of the audience  It is important because the knowledge will help us structure the message that make processing easier for the audience

quizSrc.term: Why do you need to use simple language in your presentation?
quizSrc.definition: So that it is easier for your audience to comprehend  So that it is easier for the audience to learn

quizSrc.term: Why is it important to vary your delivery style?
quizSrc.definition: To make the presentation more interesting  To help sustain the attention of the audience

quizSrc.term: What do the letters PR in the acronym, "Change PR-I-EST-S" stand for?
quizSrc.definition: Present important information or provide incentives,

quizSrc.term: A metaphor is a figure of speech used to compare two things, which are different, but have something in common. When is it useful to use one?
quizSrc.definition: When the other person is resistant to your idea and disagrees.  When the person feels threatened by trying something new.  When the person you're speaking to is unable to grasp what you're saying and you need to explain it differently.

quizSrc.term: The presentation technique of creating tension using "What is" versus "What is possible" is best employed at what stage of presentation?
quizSrc.definition: Beginning

quizSrc.term: Why would you use a cliffhanger and not finish your story?
quizSrc.definition: To challenge your audience to come up with different endings and to stay engaged.  To keep the loop open so that your audience stays engaged and wants to contact you afterwards.

quizSrc.term: A client thinks that the cost of your services is too high. Which is the best metaphor to choose:
quizSrc.definition: A metaphor about how paying for cheaper products always ends up costing more.

quizSrc.term: Should you use a story at the beginning of a presentation? Why or why not?
quizSrc.definition: Yes, it allows you to relax as you talk about something you are familiar with and connect emotionally with the audience.  Yes, it allows you to introduce the main theme of the presentation in an easy-to-listen-to way.
